Award.AwardTitle: Materials from High Molecular Weight Cyclic Polymers: Insights on Properties and Dynamics
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL SUMMARY

Polymers are ubiquitous; these materials, made of long-chain molecules comprise all modern plastics, the fibers of textiles, and the key molecules of biology including proteins and DNA. This project will leverage a new method for creating large cyclic polymers to learn how connecting a long molecule into a ring influences the properties of materials generated from these cyclic structures. Cyclic polymers differ from linear polymers by just a single bond, but this minor chemical change influences how these molecules flow during processing, how they solidify and how they interact with their environment in ways that remain poorly understood.

The planned research targets three specific aims. The first aim focuses on the generation of new classes of materials derived from cyclic polymers entrapped in cross-linked molecular networks to investigate how such an entangled cyclic chain influences the properties of the material. The second aim seeks to illuminate how cyclic molecules flow to gain a better understanding of how ring-like molecules entangle with one another and with linear chain molecules. The third aim focuses on the influence of a cyclic structure on the shapes that these large molecules adopt in the liquid and solid states.

This project will suport and educate two graduate students, who will have the opportunity to collaborate with leading experts from foreign countries and at US National Labs. The Principal Investigator and the graduate students will engage in outreach programs at local schools to promote increased scientific understanding in the community at large.


TECHNICAL SUMMARY

This research focuses on investigations of the conformation, properties, and applications of large cyclic polymers by leveraging previous advances in a new synthetic method for generating large cyclic chains. Zwitterionic ring opening polymerization (ZROP) produces large cyclic molecules by generating propagating chains that contain both a positively-charged end and a propagating negatively charged chain end. Three classes of polymers synthesized with this method will be used to achieve the above-stated goals. Water-soluble cyclic polyphosphoesters will be entrapped in three-dimensional, cross-linked hydrogel networks to investigate how the entrapped cyclic chains influence the properties of the resultant double-network hydrogels. These novel materials are anticipated to exhibit enhanced toughness relative to gels lacking the entrapped chains. The rheological behavior of high molecular-weight cyclic carbosiloxane polymers will be investigated to illuminate how cyclic molecules entangle. These materials are of a length approximately 125 times the entanglement molecular weight (Me) of the corresponding linear chains -- a molecular weight regime previously unattainable by any other synthetic method. These studies are aimed at investigating whether large cyclic chains can exhibit a plateau modulus that is typical of linear chain behavior. Neutron-scattering experiments of deuteriated high molecular weight cyclic polycaprolactones will be carried out to validate theoretical predictions that concentrated solutions of cyclic chains will exhibit collapsed conformations.

The interdisciplinary nature of this project will provide an exceptional educational environment for students trained in polymer synthesis to interact with world experts in polymer rheology, polymer physics, neutron scattering, and modern chromatographic separations.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The goal of this project was to investigate the properties of polymeric materials derived from cyclic polymers and to illuminate the conformational and dynamic properties of these materials in solution, within three- dimensional networks and as solid materials.  Polymers are ubiquitous; these large chain molecules comprise all modern plastics, the fibers of textiles, and the key molecules of biology including proteins and DNA. Cyclic polymers differ from linear polymers by their topology; when linear chain molecules are connected at their ends into a ring, this minor chemical change influences how these molecules flow, how they solidify and how they interact with their environment.

            This project sought to elicit new materials properties by generating materials incorporating cyclic ring polymers.  New methods were developed for (1) generating cyclic polymers of different compositions, functional groups and size, (2) generating novel hydrogels derived from cross-linked networks entrapping cyclic chains, and (3) generating topological gels by the self-assembly of linear triblock copolymers into flower micelles followed by cyclization of the chain-ends in the core of the micelles with reversible, dynamic bonds derived from 1,2-dithiolanes (5-membered disulfide rings).

            The intellectual merit of the project derived from the discovery that topological gels derived from dynamically cyclized chains in flower micelles exhibit dynamic behavior; these materials flow under deformation, can be injected through a small-gauge syringe, but are self-healing and recover their properties upon removal of the deformation. Investigations on the evaporative crystallization of these novel hydrogels derived from the cyclized dithiolane block copolymers reveals that they crystallize into novel cubic morphologies with dimensions on the order of 100 nm.  Thus this strategy provides a means of generating materials with novel properties where cyclic topologies are created by self-assembly and reversible crosslinking of the hydrophobic termini of ambiphilic triblock copolymers; the self-assembly and crystallization of these materials  provides a simple way of creating non-spherical polymeric nanoparticles.

            Broader impacts of the project derive from the demonstration that a zwitterionic ring-opening polymerization strategy provide a robust and versatile method for generating cyclic polymers with novel structures. Dynamic hydrogels based on the reversible cyclization of triblock copolymers represent a new class of hydrogels with interesting responsive behavior.  The concept of trapping cyclics in a crosslinked gel represents a novel direction for complex gels, as the cyclic polymers are permanently trapped yet retain some ability to flow within the second network. This project provided rich opportunities for graduate student training in materials chemistry, analysis of the structure and dynamics of cyclic polymers and materials generated therefrom, and the characterization of the dynamic properties of novel hydrogels incorporating cyclic chains as structural and dynamic elements. Graduate students on the project benefited from collaborative investigations with national and international experts in rheology and liquid chromatography at the chromatographic critical condition (LCCC).  These collaborative efforts have encouraged the students to expand the scope of their education, to learn how to work as part of a collaborative team, and to acquire new skills to advance their studies, illustrating the broader impacts of the project.


Last Modified: 09/28/2018
Modified by: Robert M Waymouth
POR.POR_COPY_TXT: The goal of this project was to investigate the properties of polymeric materials derived from cyclic polymers and to illuminate the conformational and dynamic properties of these materials in solution, within three- dimensional networks and as solid materials. Polymers are ubiquitous; these large chain molecules comprise all modern plastics, the fibers of textiles, and the key molecules of biology including proteins and DNA. Cyclic polymers differ from linear polymers by their topology; when linear chain molecules are connected at their ends into a ring, this minor chemical change influences how these molecules flow, how they solidify and how they interact with their environment. This project sought to elicit new materials properties by generating materials incorporating cyclic ring polymers. New methods were developed for (1) generating cyclic polymers of different compositions, functional groups and size, (2) generating novel hydrogels derived from cross-linked networks entrapping cyclic chains, and (3) generating topological gels by the self-assembly of linear triblock copolymers into flower micelles followed by cyclization of the chain-ends in the core of the micelles with reversible, dynamic bonds derived from 1,2-dithiolanes (5-membered disulfide rings). The intellectual merit of the project derived from the discovery that topological gels derived from dynamically cyclized chains in flower micelles exhibit dynamic behavior; these materials flow under deformation, can be injected through a small-gauge syringe, but are self-healing and recover their properties upon removal of the deformation. Investigations on the evaporative crystallization of these novel hydrogels derived from the cyclized dithiolane block copolymers reveals that they crystallize into novel cubic morphologies with dimensions on the order of 100 nm. Thus this strategy provides a means of generating materials with novel properties where cyclic topologies are created by self-assembly and reversible crosslinking of the hydrophobic termini of ambiphilic triblock copolymers; the self-assembly and crystallization of these materials provides a simple way of creating non-spherical polymeric nanoparticles. Broader impacts of the project derive from the demonstration that a zwitterionic ring-opening polymerization strategy provide a robust and versatile method for generating cyclic polymers with novel structures. Dynamic hydrogels based on the reversible cyclization of triblock copolymers represent a new class of hydrogels with interesting responsive behavior. The concept of trapping cyclics in a crosslinked gel represents a novel direction for complex gels, as the cyclic polymers are permanently trapped yet retain some ability to flow within the second network. This project provided rich opportunities for graduate student training in materials chemistry, analysis of the structure and dynamics of cyclic polymers and materials generated therefrom, and the characterization of the dynamic properties of novel hydrogels incorporating cyclic chains as structural and dynamic elements. Graduate students on the project benefited from collaborative investigations with national and international experts in rheology and liquid chromatography at the chromatographic critical condition (LCCC). These collaborative efforts have encouraged the students to expand the scope of their education, to learn how to work as part of a collaborative team, and to acquire new skills to advance their studies, illustrating the broader impacts of the project.
